title: Current Voter Register Not Useful
text:
Politics | 14 October 2015 15:53 CET Current Voter Register Not Useful By Daily Guide 
Former National Chairman of the New Patriotic Party (NPP), Peter Mac Manu, says the current voter register has outlived its usefulness. 
He said it could therefore not be used for the 2016 parliamentary and presidential elections, reiterating the need for a new voter register. 
Mr Mac Manu, who was speaking at OccupyGhana's one-year anniversary forum in Accra, said there is the need for a new voter register that contains names of Ghanaians only. 
'The current voter register is of no use again because it is bloated and contains names of foreign nationals. We need a new one,' he stressed. 
Mr Mac Manu said the bloated Ghanaian register contains names of nationals of various countries in the ECOWAS sub-region, stating, 'We will not sit down for ECOWAS to determine who will be Ghana's president.' 
He said the Electoral Commission (EC) has no other choice than to change the voter register because the evidence the party has provided is overwhelming. 
According to Mr Mac Manu, the new register would ensure that only Ghanaians would vote come 2016, underscoring the party’s resolve to ensure a new register is used for the 2016 general elections. 
The NPP, after painstaking investigations, revealed that more than 76,000 names of Togolese nationals who are registered to vote in their country are in the Ghanaian electoral roll. 
The Togolese nationals, according to the opposition party, crossed the Ghanaian border and registered to enable them exercise their franchise in the nation’s elections. 
This exposÃ© is meant to make a strong case for the EC to compile a new register to avoid problems in 2016. 
OccupyGhana Wants Observer Status Meanwhile pressure group, OccupyGhana, has applied to the Electoral Commission to be given an observer status to enable its members monitor the 2016 general elections. 
The group which has been at the forefront of political activism, particularly against corruption in the country, says it is keen to ensure that next year's elections are free and fair and results declared accepted. 
Sydney Casley Hayford, a leading member of the pressure group, announced this at the forum and revealed that the group would set up “machines” at polling stations across the country. 
He said 'Every activity at the polling stations would be monitored to ensure that we are going to get free and open elections.' 
Casley Hayford disclosed that some people have been distributing fake birth certificates to Ghanaians to allow them to register as voters. 
'There are rumours that fake birth certificates are being distributed to people so they can register and vote in 2016. We are cautioning Ghanaians to beware,' he said.
